Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Budget and Impacts of Atmospheric Organic Acids from Ground and Space-based Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Formic and acetic acids are the dominant carboxylic acids in the atmosphere. They exert an important influence on atmospheric aqueous chemistry through their effect on precipitation acidity, aqueous hydroxyl radical concentrations, and possibly secondary organic aerosol formation. This CAREER award focuses on understanding seasonal sources of organic acids and their atmospheric impacts. The research will be guided by the following key questions: What is the global importance of direct emissions versus secondary production from biogenic, biomass burning, and anthropogenic sources? Is there a significant source of formic and acetic acids during aging of organic aerosols? What is the role of formic and acetic acids in governing the acidity of precipitation and clouds around the world? How does this vary geographically and seasonally? The experimental approach combines new process-oriented measurements with new global observations from space, interpreted in the framework of an atmospheric model. Specific steps will include carrying out new field and laboratory measurements to quantify key controls on organic acid abundance in the atmosphere, applying new satellite retrievals of formic acid from the Tropospheric Emission Spectrometer and the Infrared Atmospheric Sounding Interferometer in targeted process studies on the global scale, and using the GEOS-Chem chemical transport model to interpret the new space-borne and in situ measurements in terms of quantitative constraints on global sources and chemical impacts organic acids in the atmosphere.

The broader impacts of this work will include: 1) Enhanced learning in air pollution and Earth Science for local public elementary students; 2) Training graduate and postdoctoral researchers in cutting-edge atmospheric chemistry measurement and modeling tools; 3) Building the research and education capacity of the new Land and Atmospheric Science program at the University of Minnesota; 4) Better understanding of organic acid sources and impacts for more accurate air quality and climate predictions; 5) Active dissemination of scientific findings through scientific presentations and publications. Finalized measurement data, satellite retrievals, and model code will be made public and readily available online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve scientific understanding of the sources, sinks, and impacts of carboxylic acids and related volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in Earth’s atmosphere. Carboxylic acids are an important source of acidity, and affect key in-cloud reactions in the atmosphere. More generally, VOCs play a central role in the atmosphere as precursors of ozone and particulate matter, and by affecting the atmosphere’s oxidizing capacity (via the hydroxyl radical). Some key results from this research project are highlighted below.

New atmospheric measurements of formic acid from space.We developed and validated a new retrieval algorithm for measuring atmospheric formic acid from the TES (Thermal Emission Spectrometer) satellite sensor (see Figure 1). These data provide a new global dataset for investigating the global distribution and sources of this key atmospheric acid, and support prior work showing that there is much more formic acid in the atmosphere than can be explained based on its known sources. These new measurements are now publicly available as part of the TES archive.

The global source of formic acid from fires was previously underestimated.We used the new satellite measurements described above to show that current emission inventories underestimate the source of formic acid from open burning (forest fires, savannah fires, agricultural fires, etc.) by approximately a factor of 10 (see Figure 2). This same analysis also demonstrated that the source of formic acid from fires is not large enough to account for the missing sources highlighted earlier.

New methods developments for measuring atmospheric carboxylic acids.This project contributed new analytical tools and procedures for measuring carboxylic acids and related atmospheric VOCs by proton-transfer-reaction mass spectrometry. 

Quantifying the importance of a newly-discovered source of atmospheric formic acid.As part of this project, we applied an atmospheric model to assess the importance of a newly-discovered source of atmospheric formic acid: photo-tautomerization of acetaldehyde. We showed that this source only has minor importance over land, but can be a significant fraction of the total known formic acid source over oceans.

A new global assessment of the atmospheric budget of formic acid. We developed an improved model simulation of atmospheric formic acid, and used it to interpret recent atmospheric measurements in terms of the information they provide on the sources of this compound (see Figure 3). Findings suggested that a large natural source from vegetation, plus atmospheric production from a range of precursor VOCs, is required to explain the abundance of atmospheric formic acid. The new model tools developed under this work are now incorporated into the standard version of the GEOS-Chem atmospheric model for general use by the scientific community.

Improved estimates of VOC emissions and air pollution over India.India is a global hotspot for air pollution-related mortality, but due to lack of measurements there is poor understanding of emission sources in the region that contribute to poor air quality. This project enabled the development of a new high-resolution atmospheric model simulation for studying air pollution over India. This new tool has contributed to a better understanding of VOC emissions and air quality in this region, and is being used by research groups at multiple institutions.

Role of nighttime chemistry for ozone air pollution.Field measurements performed under this project revealed an unexpected an unexpected mechanism by which natural and human-caused emissions can interact to cause ozone pollution in cities downwind of forests. The mechanism involves the nighttime chemistry of isoprene (the most important natural VOC), and the findings have implications for air quality predictions in such areas.

Emission and uptake of VOCs by forests.Forest ecosystems are simultaneously the largest source and a major sink of VOCs to the global atmosphere, and this two-way exchange is an important source of uncertainty in current atmospheric models. Field measurements and modeling under this project contributed to a better understanding of the emission and deposition of VOCs between forests and the atmosphere (see Figure 4), and of the importance of unknown or missing VOCs. 

Summary.The scientific results from this work contribute to a better understanding of atmospheric VOCs, which supports more accurate predictions of atmospheric composition and air quality. Findings have been disseminated via conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications. Several tools and datasets from this work are publicly available for use by the broader community.
